Would feasible U.S. replace tariffs revenue-sharing trade model export-reliant countries remit small percentage tax revenue collected U.S.-bound goods? U.S. currently using tariffs trade restrictions primary tools influence trade relationships protect domestic industries. According Council Foreign Relations, tariffs designed protect local industries making imports expensive, thereby encouraging consumers buy domestically produced goods. However, tariffs also increase prices consumers reduce national income. 2019 study published *Quarterly Journal Economics* found tariffs imposed U.S. 2018 led $51 billion increase costs U.S. consumers firms, net real income loss $7.8 billion.² Similarly, Congressional Budget Office CBO reported 2020 tariffs implemented 2018 2020 would reduce U.S. real GDP 0.5% increase average consumer prices 0.5%, average household income loss $1,277. Would effective sustainable U.S. negotiate trade access using different mechanism — requiring partner countries remit small percentage tax revenue collected goods exported U.S.? example, country exports $20B goods U.S. annually agrees remit 1.5% goods, U.S. could collect $300M without directly impacting consumer prices. structure would maintain price stability reinforcing idea access U.S. consumer market privilege associated obligations. exporting country still generating tax revenue goods — model would simply give U.S. share pie. similar Apple App Store: developers gain access massive marketplace, pay percentage return. government ever implemented model like this? Would practical beneficial alternative tariffs? **Sources:** ¹ Amiti, M., Redding, S. J., & Weinstein, D. E. 2019. Impact 2018 Trade War U.S. Prices Welfare. *Quarterly Journal Economics*.
